Expectation1: Communicate any challenges or concerns promptly to the mentor.
Situation1: A serious conflict with teammates is threatening the mentee’s deliverable timeline.
Situation2: Got a request to attend court to provide testimony when required.
Story: I stared at my phone, the message from my mentor blinking on the screen: “Let me know if you’re facing any issues with the project.” My stomach twisted. The truth was, my teammates and I had hit a wall—arguments flared daily, and our deliverable was slipping through our fingers. I knew I should reach out, be honest, and ask for help, just as my mentor expected. But then my police radio crackled, and I was reminded of my other duty. I’d just received a court summons, scheduled for the same day as our project’s final review. As a police officer, I was expected to act with integrity, to show up and testify when called, no matter what. I felt torn in two—my mentor counted on my transparency, my team needed me to pull us together, but the law demanded my presence in court. My mind raced, guilt and anxiety battling inside me. I couldn’t see a way to meet both expectations, and the weight of letting someone down pressed heavily on my chest as I sat frozen, unable to choose which role to betray.
